newsitem.title: USA: Dlr closes mixed in U.S. as slide vs yen continues.
newsitem.headline: Dlr closes mixed in U.S. as slide vs yen continues.

text.p: The dollar fell against the yen Tuesday, extending overnight losses after a troika of Japanese economic leaders voiced concern over the recent dollar rally.
Late in U.S. trade, the dollar was again hit by negative comments -- this time from Gail Fosler, chief economist at the Conference Board, a private economic research firm.
Fosler told an audience in Washington that the dollar was 15 percent overvalued against the yen, fueling a brief flurry of dollar selling, dealers said.
The dollar slipped to just below 115 yen on the news before bargain-hunters emerged to bolster the currency.

"The Conference Board is just an independent group, but the dollar has been trading heavily for the last couple of days, so it was poised for some retracement on a comment like that," said Russell Lascala, chief spot trader at Citibank.
The dollar closed lower at 115.23/28 yen from 115.38/48 at the open and an overnight high of 115.98. The dollar edged higher to 1.5640/45 marks from 1.5610/20 in uninspired trade.
The comments came one day after similar remarks from a Japanese finance official caused a dollar slide and reinforced perceptions that Japan may act to slow the dollar's ascent.
